EN (not my native language)  Having played more than 3000 hours on this game to date, I think I am legitimate to give my point of view :  Stellaris is the best 4X I've played. Among its strengths we find  - graphics I believe quite correct for a game of this age, and especially for a 4x - An incredible immersion thanks to its many stories - a mind-blowing replayability: many empire and galaxy configurations are possible. Victory is possible in many ways. - advanced gameplay mechanics (we have an empire at the beginning, but in the end almost everything is modifiable during the game) - an interesting combat system, more complicated than it seems to face different fleets. It is no longer enough to have the biggest to win.  As nothing is perfect I have listed in my opinion what is missing for the game to be really perfect : - an economic war system is for me the biggest weak point of the game: I find it a pity that an economically powerful empire cannot, with a lot of resources, influence and put other enemy empires into crisis. The espionage system is too marginal in my opinion. For example, an idea would be to create a terrorist camp in the opposing country with the espionage system. This would create a faction without a planet at the beginning, but with which we could interact to give them resources, influence, in order to undermine the opposing country (increase in pirate fleets, decrease in trade income, attacks / devastation on planets etc...) A threat that ultimately could not be countered by the targeted empire only by allocating resources to the anti-terrorist threat, so a war more economic than military in the end. Why not, simply allocate substantial resources to reduce the income of an opposing empire. A condition could be the commercial link / commercial pact between two empires (unfair competition?, maybe only for Megacrop, or more efficient for megaCorp). This would make it possible to be friend-enemy of an empire, even within a federation. Because I find that federations are too strong today, and are too difficult to break once formed. Encouraging the members of the federations to be selfish (cf: theory of non-zero sum games), would better reflect real politics and diplomacy in the game, and would give a less static part. - maybe a redesign of the psy ascension, a bit like the update of the synthetic ascension. - a better breed management system for those who choose genetic ascension. - can be a redesign of ground combat (ex; support for fleets in orbit, leaf stone system, chisel with the terrestrial, terrestrial army design with shield system, armor and hit point would be interesting. Maybe a militia / resistance system, which would force the conqueror to leave part of his army on the conquered planet to stop the militia rebellion. These rebellions would be orchestrated by the empire having lost its planet via a decision, at the cost of influence and part of the population to recover its lost territory. As in reality, it seems unlikely that if an alien species lands on earth to destroy all our armies, just installs a governor, and all his army leaves, it is unlikely that the human species would not rise as soon as they leave.  Finally, the community is very active, and the mods are extremely numerous, which brings a real richness in terms of content, and even more customization of the games played.  You would have understood it: I recommend the game. Updates are frequent, the improvement of the game is still in progress. Although the price of the DLC may put some off, I think it is the price to bring a game of this magnitude and complexity to life. The implementation of the subscription is, in my opinion, a good idea, and allows a player not to invest a lot of money to know if the game will please him or not. Just like the advance purchase of future DLC is also, in my opinion, a good idea. It allows regular players to immediately buy the future DLC with a discount, and the developers to have some extra money (you have to see their point of view too)

I have many hours on this game. But today, Paradox and Steam's update policy obliges me to give it a negative review.  In over 1000 hours of play, I'VE NEVER BEEN ABLE TO FINISH A SINGLE GAME. Here's why. I like to take the time to manage every detail of my slowly growing empire. I play at minimum speed. A single game can take me several hundred hours to complete. And as a casual gamer, several months IRL. In a word, I'm an "old game" grand strategy player: meticulous and occasional.  Paradox regularly updates its game. And every new update is likely to be incompatible with the saves of games in progress. The Steam launcher does everything it can to force these updates. On several occasions, I've blocked updates in order to continue playing... Unfortunately, Steam sometimes arbitrarily lifts this update block. What's more, it doesn't prevent mods from updating, which similarly destroy my save. And finding old versions of mods on old Github in the hope of tinkering with compatibility to be able to continue a save is a purge...  Since I started on Stellaris, every single one of my parties has ended up being broken by a game update. EVERY SINGLE ONE.  A few months ago, I took the precaution of blocking new releases. I launched a new game. 3.12 arrived, and with it, the update of certain mods. Steam didn't take my update block into account...  For two days now, I've been trying in vain to tinker with my files to recover my save, which I can't manage to relaunch. I thin it's fucked. Again.   This game is good. But for old school players like me, it's fucked by the update policy and by Steam.

This is not a game , this is a chore.  Everything is hidden in multitude of screens which takes a ridiculous amount of time to navigate. Doing anything is unintuitive as possible. Want to move a ship ? You have to open the ship menu , then click to the move button then select the star system. If you can't do it, nothing will tell you why and everything will be resetted for you to try again. When you have one ship , it's already cumbersome , now imagine when you have 20 on them !!  Numbers of tasks and event demand you to do something but it's never clear what they want and even when you seemingly have what it requires , example need a science-ship in the sector with a scientist , somehow it will still NOT work out because a hidden condition that you have to somehow now from a comment found in the forum.  The early game alone is very time consuming as a player while not actively doing anything ! As a result, you are basically forced to put everything on automatic and prey everything will go well. You're basically watching the game play itself or "work" on your game !   Ridiculous. I only recommend to players who want to have 2nd and 3rd job in a game where you will spend most of the time navigating in menus and screens... 2/20

ENGLISH :  Stellaris is a masterpiece among strategy games, and video games in general. Its immensity tends to make it terribly time consuming and addictive!  Since its release, this game has been continuously updated, especially through numerous expensive DLC, of a quality always appreciable. This policy, dear to Paradox, can easily put off players from embarking on the adventure that is Stellaris, for fear of not having access to the entire game. When you start for the first time a game of Stellaris, it is normal to be completely lost, between the local management of the populations of your planets, your diplomacy with the Xenos, the internal politics of your empire. It's impossible to go over every detail that makes Stellaris unique and perfect, because the possibilities are so great and can be adapted to your every desire. A great freedom in the creation and management of your species and its empire . A wonderful soundtrack . Simple but beautiful graphics  Weaknesses :  . A policy of DLC sometimes too aggressive despite their quality . The game slows down at the end of the game because of the increasing number of elements to process  To buy without hesitation!

EN (not my native language)  Having played more than 3000 hours on this game to date, I think I am legitimate to give my point of view :  Stellaris is the best 4X I've played. Among its strengths we find  - graphics I believe quite correct for a game of this age, and especially for a 4x - An incredible immersion thanks to its many stories - a mind-blowing replayability: many empire and galaxy configurations are possible. Victory is possible in many ways. - advanced gameplay mechanics (we have an empire at the beginning, but in the end almost everything is modifiable during the game) - an interesting combat system, more complicated than it seems to face different fleets. It is no longer enough to have the biggest to win.  As nothing is perfect I have listed in my opinion what is missing for the game to be really perfect : - an economic war system is for me the biggest weak point of the game: I find it a pity that an economically powerful empire cannot, with a lot of resources, influence and put other enemy empires into crisis. The espionage system is too marginal in my opinion. For example, an idea would be to create a terrorist camp in the opposing country with the espionage system. This would create a faction without a planet at the beginning, but with which we could interact to give them resources, influence, in order to undermine the opposing country (increase in pirate fleets, decrease in trade income, attacks / devastation on planets etc...) A threat that ultimately could not be countered by the targeted empire only by allocating resources to the anti-terrorist threat, so a war more economic than military in the end. Why not, simply allocate substantial resources to reduce the income of an opposing empire. A condition could be the commercial link / commercial pact between two empires (unfair competition?, maybe only for Megacrop, or more efficient for megaCorp). This would make it possible to be friend-enemy of an empire, even within a federation. Because I find that federations are too strong today, and are too difficult to break once formed. Encouraging the members of the federations to be selfish (cf: theory of non-zero sum games), would better reflect real politics and diplomacy in the game, and would give a less static part. - maybe a redesign of the psy ascension, a bit like the update of the synthetic ascension. - a better breed management system for those who choose genetic ascension. - can be a redesign of ground combat (ex; support for fleets in orbit, leaf stone system, chisel with the terrestrial, terrestrial army design with shield system, armor and hit point would be interesting. Maybe a militia / resistance system, which would force the conqueror to leave part of his army on the conquered planet to stop the militia rebellion. These rebellions would be orchestrated by the empire having lost its planet via a decision, at the cost of influence and part of the population to recover its lost territory. As in reality, it seems unlikely that if an alien species lands on earth to destroy all our armies, just installs a governor, and all his army leaves, it is unlikely that the human species would not rise as soon as they leave.  Finally, the community is very active, and the mods are extremely numerous, which brings a real richness in terms of content, and even more customization of the games played.  You would have understood it: I recommend the game. Updates are frequent, the improvement of the game is still in progress. Although the price of the DLC may put some off, I think it is the price to bring a game of this magnitude and complexity to life. The implementation of the subscription is, in my opinion, a good idea, and allows a player not to invest a lot of money to know if the game will please him or not. Just like the advance purchase of future DLC is also, in my opinion, a good idea. It allows regular players to immediately buy the future DLC with a discount, and the developers to have some extra money (you have to see their point of view too)

I have many hours on this game. But today, Paradox and Steam's update policy obliges me to give it a negative review.  In over 1000 hours of play, I'VE NEVER BEEN ABLE TO FINISH A SINGLE GAME. Here's why. I like to take the time to manage every detail of my slowly growing empire. I play at minimum speed. A single game can take me several hundred hours to complete. And as a casual gamer, several months IRL. In a word, I'm an "old game" grand strategy player: meticulous and occasional.  Paradox regularly updates its game. And every new update is likely to be incompatible with the saves of games in progress. The Steam launcher does everything it can to force these updates. On several occasions, I've blocked updates in order to continue playing... Unfortunately, Steam sometimes arbitrarily lifts this update block. What's more, it doesn't prevent mods from updating, which similarly destroy my save. And finding old versions of mods on old Github in the hope of tinkering with compatibility to be able to continue a save is a purge...  Since I started on Stellaris, every single one of my parties has ended up being broken by a game update. EVERY SINGLE ONE.  A few months ago, I took the precaution of blocking new releases. I launched a new game. 3.12 arrived, and with it, the update of certain mods. Steam didn't take my update block into account...  For two days now, I've been trying in vain to tinker with my files to recover my save, which I can't manage to relaunch. I thin it's fucked. Again.   This game is good. But for old school players like me, it's fucked by the update policy and by Steam.

This is not a game , this is a chore.  Everything is hidden in multitude of screens which takes a ridiculous amount of time to navigate. Doing anything is unintuitive as possible. ENGLISH :  Stellaris is a masterpiece among strategy games, and video games in general. Its immensity tends to make it terribly time consuming and addictive!  Since its release, this game has been continuously updated, especially through numerous expensive DLC, of a quality always appreciable. This policy, dear to Paradox, can easily put off players from embarking on the adventure that is Stellaris, for fear of not having access to the entire game. But I'm telling you, even without those DLC, the game is still a wonder! So, with them, we reach degrees of perfection rarely achieve!  When you start for the first time a game of Stellaris, it is normal to be completely lost, between the local management of the populations of your planets, your diplomacy with the Xenos, the internal politics of your empire. But, after the first few hours, it's quite difficult to get the hang of it, and it's a very, very extensive universe that is offered to you: you want to create a paradise where all the sentient species of the galaxy cohabit and prosper? A company that sells its products wherever money exists? An empire whose economy is based on the massive cloning of slaves to sell them? All this is possible, and it is only a small part of all the possibilities that Stellaris offers.  It's impossible to go over every detail that makes Stellaris unique and perfect, because the possibilities are so great and can be adapted to your every desire. Even after 1000 hours spent conquering, exploring, warring, developing, trading, you will continue to be surprised by this game, by what it has to offer. And, last but not least, if you like the game as is, then the DLC will increase your enjoyment and interest tenfold.  Strengths : . Infinite replayability without the feeling of repetition . A great freedom in the creation and management of your species and its empire . A wonderful soundtrack . Simple but beautiful graphics  Weaknesses :  . A policy of DLC sometimes too aggressive despite their quality . The game slows down at the end of the game because of the increasing number of elements to process  To buy without hesitation!

EN (not my native language)  Having played more than 3000 hours on this game to date, I think I am legitimate to give my point of view :  Stellaris is the best 4X I've played. Among its strengths we find  - graphics I believe quite correct for a game of this age, and especially for a 4x - An incredible immersion thanks to its many stories - a mind-blowing replayability: many empire and galaxy configurations are possible. Victory is possible in many ways. - advanced gameplay mechanics (we have an empire at the beginning, but in the end almost everything is modifiable during the game) - an interesting combat system, more complicated than it seems to face different fleets. It is no longer enough to have the biggest to win.  As nothing is perfect I have listed in my opinion what is missing for the game to be really perfect : - an economic war system is for me the biggest weak point of the game: I find it a pity that an economically powerful empire cannot, with a lot of resources, influence and put other enemy empires into crisis. The espionage system is too marginal in my opinion. For example, an idea would be to create a terrorist camp in the opposing country with the espionage system. This would create a faction without a planet at the beginning, but with which we could interact to give them resources, influence, in order to undermine the opposing country (increase in pirate fleets, decrease in trade income, attacks / devastation on planets etc...) A threat that ultimately could not be countered by the targeted empire only by allocating resources to the anti-terrorist threat, so a war more economic than military in the end. Why not, simply allocate substantial resources to reduce the income of an opposing empire. A condition could be the commercial link / commercial pact between two empires (unfair competition?, maybe only for Megacrop, or more efficient for megaCorp). This would make it possible to be friend-enemy of an empire, even within a federation. Because I find that federations are too strong today, and are too difficult to break once formed. Encouraging the members of the federations to be selfish (cf: theory of non-zero sum games), would better reflect real politics and diplomacy in the game, and would give a less static part. - maybe a redesign of the psy ascension, a bit like the update of the synthetic ascension. - a better breed management system for those who choose genetic ascension. - can be a redesign of ground combat (ex; support for fleets in orbit, leaf stone system, chisel with the terrestrial, terrestrial army design with shield system, armor and hit point would be interesting. Maybe a militia / resistance system, which would force the conqueror to leave part of his army on the conquered planet to stop the militia rebellion. These rebellions would be orchestrated by the empire having lost its planet via a decision, at the cost of influence and part of the population to recover its lost territory. As in reality, it seems unlikely that if an alien species lands on earth to destroy all our armies, just installs a governor, and all his army leaves, it is unlikely that the human species would not rise as soon as they leave.  Finally, the community is very active, and the mods are extremely numerous, which brings a real richness in terms of content, and even more customization of the games played.  You would have understood it: I recommend the game. Updates are frequent, the improvement of the game is still in progress. Although the price of the DLC may put some off, I think it is the price to bring a game of this magnitude and complexity to life. The implementation of the subscription is, in my opinion, a good idea, and allows a player not to invest a lot of money to know if the game will please him or not. Just like the advance purchase of future DLC is also, in my opinion, a good idea. It allows regular players to immediately buy the future DLC with a discount, and the developers to have some extra money (you have to see their point of view too)

I have many hours on this game. But today, Paradox and Steam's update policy obliges me to give it a negative review.  In over 1000 hours of play, I'VE NEVER BEEN ABLE TO FINISH A SINGLE GAME. Here's why. I like to take the time to manage every detail of my slowly growing empire. I play at minimum speed. A single game can take me several hundred hours to complete. And as a casual gamer, several months IRL. In a word, I'm an "old game" grand strategy player: meticulous and occasional.  Paradox regularly updates its game. And every new update is likely to be incompatible with the saves of games in progress. The Steam launcher does everything it can to force these updates. On several occasions, I've blocked updates in order to continue playing... Unfortunately, Steam sometimes arbitrarily lifts this update block. What's more, it doesn't prevent mods from updating, which similarly destroy my save. And finding old versions of mods on old Github in the hope of tinkering with compatibility to be able to continue a save is a purge...  Since I started on Stellaris, every single one of my parties has ended up being broken by a game update. EVERY SINGLE ONE.  A few months ago, I took the precaution of blocking new releases. I launched a new game. 3.12 arrived, and with it, the update of certain mods. Steam didn't take my update block into account...  For two days now, I've been trying in vain to tinker with my files to recover my save, which I can't manage to relaunch. I thin it's fucked. Again.   This game is good. But for old school players like me, it's fucked by the update policy and by Steam.

This is not a game , this is a chore.  Everything is hidden in multitude of screens which takes a ridiculous amount of time to navigate. Doing anything is unintuitive as possible. Want to move a ship ? You have to open the ship menu , then click to the move button then select the star system. If you can't do it, nothing will tell you why and everything will be resetted for you to try again. When you have one ship , it's already cumbersome , now imagine when you have 20 on them !!  Numbers of tasks and event demand you to do something but it's never clear what they want and even when you seemingly have what it requires , example need a science-ship in the sector with a scientist , somehow it will still NOT work out because a hidden condition that you have to somehow now from a comment found in the forum.  The early game alone is very time consuming as a player while not actively doing anything ! As a result, you are basically forced to put everything on automatic and prey everything will go well. You're basically watching the game play itself or "work" on your game !   Ridiculous. I only recommend to players who want to have 2nd and 3rd job in a game where you will spend most of the time navigating in menus and screens... 2/20

ENGLISH :  Stellaris is a masterpiece among strategy games, and video games in general. Its immensity tends to make it terribly time consuming and addictive!  Since its release, this game has been continuously updated, especially through numerous expensive DLC, of a quality always appreciable. This policy, dear to Paradox, can easily put off players from embarking on the adventure that is Stellaris, for fear of not having access to the entire game. When you start for the first time a game of Stellaris, it is normal to be completely lost, between the local management of the populations of your planets, your diplomacy with the Xenos, the internal politics of your empire. It's impossible to go over every detail that makes Stellaris unique and perfect, because the possibilities are so great and can be adapted to your every desire. A great freedom in the creation and management of your species and its empire . A wonderful soundtrack . Simple but beautiful graphics  Weaknesses :  . A policy of DLC sometimes too aggressive despite their quality . The game slows down at the end of the game because of the increasing number of elements to process  To buy without hesitation!

EN (not my native language)  Having played more than 3000 hours on this game to date, I think I am legitimate to give my point of view :  Stellaris is the best 4X I've played. Among its strengths we find  - graphics I believe quite correct for a game of this age, and especially for a 4x - An incredible immersion thanks to its many stories - a mind-blowing replayability: many empire and galaxy configurations are possible. Victory is possible in many ways. - advanced gameplay mechanics (we have an empire at the beginning, but in the end almost everything is modifiable during the game) - an interesting combat system, more complicated than it seems to face different fleets. It is no longer enough to have the biggest to win.  As nothing is perfect I have listed in my opinion what is missing for the game to be really perfect : - an economic war system is for me the biggest weak point of the game: I find it a pity that an economically powerful empire cannot, with a lot of resources, influence and put other enemy empires into crisis. The espionage system is too marginal in my opinion. For example, an idea would be to create a terrorist camp in the opposing country with the espionage system. This would create a faction without a planet at the beginning, but with which we could interact to give them resources, influence, in order to undermine the opposing country (increase in pirate fleets, decrease in trade income, attacks / devastation on planets etc...) A threat that ultimately could not be countered by the targeted empire only by allocating resources to the anti-terrorist threat, so a war more economic than military in the end. Why not, simply allocate substantial resources to reduce the income of an opposing empire. A condition could be the commercial link / commercial pact between two empires (unfair competition?, maybe only for Megacrop, or more efficient for megaCorp). This would make it possible to be friend-enemy of an empire, even within a federation. Because I find that federations are too strong today, and are too difficult to break once formed. Encouraging the members of the federations to be selfish (cf: theory of non-zero sum games), would better reflect real politics and diplomacy in the game, and would give a less static part. - maybe a redesign of the psy ascension, a bit like the update of the synthetic ascension. - a better breed management system for those who choose genetic ascension. - can be a redesign of ground combat (ex; support for fleets in orbit, leaf stone system, chisel with the terrestrial, terrestrial army design with shield system, armor and hit point would be interesting. Maybe a militia / resistance system, which would force the conqueror to leave part of his army on the conquered planet to stop the militia rebellion. These rebellions would be orchestrated by the empire having lost its planet via a decision, at the cost of influence and part of the population to recover its lost territory. As in reality, it seems unlikely that if an alien species lands on earth to destroy all our armies, just installs a governor, and all his army leaves, it is unlikely that the human species would not rise as soon as they leave.  Finally, the community is very active, and the mods are extremely numerous, which brings a real richness in terms of content, and even more customization of the games played.  You would have understood it: I recommend the game. Updates are frequent, the improvement of the game is still in progress. Although the price of the DLC may put some off, I think it is the price to bring a game of this magnitude and complexity to life. The implementation of the subscription is, in my opinion, a good idea, and allows a player not to invest a lot of money to know if the game will please him or not. Just like the advance purchase of future DLC is also, in my opinion, a good idea. It allows regular players to immediately buy the future DLC with a discount, and the developers to have some extra money (you have to see their point of view too)

I have many hours on this game. But today, Paradox and Steam's update policy obliges me to give it a negative review.  In over 1000 hours of play, I'VE NEVER BEEN ABLE TO FINISH A SINGLE GAME. Here's why. I like to take the time to manage every detail of my slowly growing empire. I play at minimum speed. A single game can take me several hundred hours to complete. And as a casual gamer, several months IRL. In a word, I'm an "old game" grand strategy player: meticulous and occasional.  Paradox regularly updates its game. And every new update is likely to be incompatible with the saves of games in progress. The Steam launcher does everything it can to force these updates. On several occasions, I've blocked updates in order to continue playing... Unfortunately, Steam sometimes arbitrarily lifts this update block. What's more, it doesn't prevent mods from updating, which similarly destroy my save. And finding old versions of mods on old Github in the hope of tinkering with compatibility to be able to continue a save is a purge...  Since I started on Stellaris, every single one of my parties has ended up being broken by a game update. EVERY SINGLE ONE.  A few months ago, I took the precaution of blocking new releases. I launched a new game. 3.12 arrived, and with it, the update of certain mods. Steam didn't take my update block into account...  For two days now, I've been trying in vain to tinker with my files to recover my save, which I can't manage to relaunch. I thin it's fucked. Again.   This game is good. But for old school players like me, it's fucked by the update policy and by Steam.

This is not a game , this is a chore.  Everything is hidden in multitude of screens which takes a ridiculous amount of time to navigate. Doing anything is unintuitive as possible.
